item.title: ‘Where’s the Humanity?’ Bondi Attack Leaves Suspects’ Neighborhood Stunned
item.description: The alleged gunmen in the shooting, Sajid Akram, 50 and his son, Naveed Akram, 24, were from Bonnyrigg, a diverse, multilingual suburb miles from Sydney’s Bondi Beach.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Max Kim and Matthew Abbott
item.media:description: A pedestrian overpass spanning a main road on Friday in Bonnyrigg, a multicultural suburb of Sydney.

item.title: Epstein Files Timeline: How the Trump Administration Released Records
item.description: A year of political pressure and partial disclosures preceded the release of long-sought records on Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has faced persistent scrutiny over his shifting stance on the release of Justice Department files related to Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: 6 Takeaways From the First Batch of the Epstein Files
item.description: Many of the Justice Department documents were heavily redacted, and President Trump’s name was rarely mentioned. The White House also sought to make political hay of the release of photos of Bill Clinton.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

item.title: Epstein Victims Upset About Lack of Transparency in Newly Released Files
item.description: Several victims said they were frustrated by the heavy redactions of photos and documents that the Justice Department released on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Survivors spoke during a news conference on the Epstein Files Transparency Act ahead of the House vote to release the files in November.

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Administration’s Homeless Aid Plan
item.description: The proposal would have required recipients to get treatment for addiction or mental illness as a condition of receiving housing funds. The administration has said it will try again.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Geffner House, in Manhattan, provides permanent housing to low-income adults, many of whom were previously homeless.

item.title: Vivek Ramaswamy Challenges Conservatives on Surging Anti-Indian Hate
item.description: The leading Republican candidate for Ohio governor is calling out his party for rising intolerance, including against Indian American immigrants and their children, like him.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Associated Press

item.title: White House Chides Smithsonian for Delayed Turnover of Records on Programming
item.description: The institution has tried to work with the administration’s demands that it present a more uplifting view of American history.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Smithsonian Castle, home of the Smithsonian Institution administrative offices and information center, in August.

item.title: Rubio Meets (and Meets, and Meets … ) the Press
item.description: The secretary of state held a marathon news conference, offering little news but more respect for reporters than most others in the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Kevin Mohatt/Reuters
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio fielded questions from reporters for more than two hours on Friday.

item.title: Lawmakers Criticize Justice Dept. For Not Releasing All Epstein Files
item.description: Republicans and Democrats who had been pressing for the disclosure accused officials of failing to comply with a law that requires all material to be released.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, said, “Simply releasing a mountain of blacked out pages violates the spirit of transparency and the letter of the law.”

item.title: Greg Biffle’s Plane Turned Back Minutes After Takeoff
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the crash at a North Carolina airport, which killed seven people, including the driver Greg Biffle and his wife and children.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: National Assn of Stock Car Auto Racing
item.media:credit: Matt Kelley/Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency vehicles responding to the plane crash that killed the star NASCAR driver Greg Biffle, his family and three others at a regional airport in Statesville, N.C., on Thursday.

item.title: Elise Stefanik Tried Everything to Please Trump. He Still Jilted Her.
item.description: The G.O.P. congresswoman who ran as a moderate but became an “ultra MAGA” Trump acolyte ultimately found herself undermined by the president and politically adrift.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elise Stefanik’s tumble from grace crystallized the limits of MAGA loyalty and the risks of building a political identity around President Trump.

item.title: Epstein Files Include 1996 Child Porn Complaint That F.B.I. Ignored
item.description: Newly released files show how Maria Farmer, who worked for Mr. Epstein in the 1990s, had urged the F.B.I. to investigate him. The case went nowhere for years.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Andrea Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Farmer in 2019.

item.title: Justice Dept. Will Appeal Dismissal of Comey and James Indictments
item.description: The Trump administration had vowed to fight a judge’s decision to dismiss unrelated criminal charges against James Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and Letitia James, the attorney general of New York.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: William B. Plowman/NBCUniversal, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A federal judge last month dismissed the criminal case against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, on the grounds that Lindsey Halligan had been unlawfully appointed to a top prosecutor position.

item.title: Trump Is Rarely Mentioned in New Epstein Files
item.description: The files that The Times initially reviewed on Friday included only a handful of references to or images of Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich

item.title: Trump Picks New Leader for Southern Command as Venezuela Pressure Grows
item.description: Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan, a Marine general with expansive experience in special operations and the Middle East, would take over after the abrupt departure of the previous commander.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: U.S. Marine Corps
item.media:description: If confirmed by the Senate, Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan would take over as boat strikes in the Caribbean and Pacific have come under sharp criticism from lawmakers from both parties.

item.title: Suspect in Brown and M.I.T. Killings Died 2 Days Before He Was Found, Autopsy Shows
item.description: The examination confirmed that the suspect had died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. His body was found late Thursday in a storage unit in New Hampshire.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: The suspect’s body was found in a storage facility in Salem, N.H., late Thursday.

item.title: Bill Clinton Features Prominently in Epstein Files Release
item.description: The focus on a former president comes at a moment when Republicans have fought to shift public attention away from Mr. Epstein’s friendship with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Confessore, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Benner

item.title: Introducing Your Next Newsletter Writer (for Now), and Looking Back at 2025
item.description: There will be much to dive into when On Politics returns in January, and a familiar voice will be taking the helm — at least for a little while.
item.dc:creator: Jess Bidgood
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at his inauguration.

item.title: Kennedy Center, Memorial to JFK, Is Trump’s Now, Too
item.description: The Kennedy Center installed President Trump’s name on the facade of the arts center, which had been designated as a living memorial to President John F. Kennedy.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crew members unveiling the new name of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Friday morning.

item.title: For Trump, Epstein is the story that won’t go away.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Thomas Corcordia/Getty Images
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump with Jeffrey Epstein in New York City in 1997.

item.title: What is the origin of the Epstein case?
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein and his onetime girlfriend Ghislaine Maxwell were charged by authorities for abuse.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Islamic State Targets in Syria
item.description: American forces struck dozens of suspected ISIS sites, making good on President Trump’s vow to avenge two American soldiers and a civilian U.S. interpreter killed by the group last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The dignified transfer of the American soldiers killed in Syria. The assault last weekend was a stark reminder of the danger in the region and the quandary of whether to keep American forces there at all.

item.title: Trump’s Name Joins Kennedy’s on Performing Arts Center’s Facade
item.description: Workers hauled up large letters spelling out Mr. Trump’s full name to add to the white marble face of the building on Friday morning.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh and Chris Cameron
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s name was added to the facade of the John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Friday.

item.title: How to See the Epstein Files Released on Friday
item.description: The searchable database published by the Justice Department is broken into multiple categories.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold

item.title: How The Times is covering the latest release of Epstein files.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Scott C. Beardsley Named University of Virginia’s New President
item.description: The selection of Scott Beardsley by the G.O.P.-appointed board comes after the previous president resigned under pressure from the Trump administration. A new Democratic-appointed board could try to overturn the choice.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of Virginia campus in Charlottesville, Va.

item.title: How the T.S.A. Is Helping ICE
item.description: In a previously undisclosed partnership, the Transportation Security Administration and Immigration and Customs Enforcement are sharing data to identify passengers on upcoming flights whom ICE can arrest. Our reporter Hamed Aleaziz, who learned of this partnership, describes what to know about it and the ICE arrests that have followed.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz, Melanie Bencosme, June Kim, Pierre Kattar and Whitney Shefte

item.title: The untold story of how Jeffrey Epstein got rich.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich, Steve Eder, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Alan Feuer and Michael Gold

item.title: Supreme Court Refuses to Halt Free Speech Lawsuit From Immigration Judges
item.description: The case, brought by the union representing immigration judges, could have implications for other workplace claims brought by government officials.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.category: United States Office of Special Counsel
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The immediate issue for the Supreme Court concerned the proper venue for resolving employee complaints.

item.title: How Venezuela Went From U.S. Ally to Trump Target
item.description: Closely tied to Washington during much of the Cold War, Venezuela has gone through political upheavals over the years that now make it a major enemy in the eyes of the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Henry Griffin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Venezuelans surrounding Vice President Richard M. Nixon’s motorcade in Caracas in 1958.

item.title: U.S. Kills 5 People Accused of Trafficking Drugs in Another Boat Strike
item.description: The attack killed 5 people, the latest known fatalities since the attacks began in September. The Trump administration has accused those on the boats of ferrying narcotics but provided little proof.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pentagon officials on Thursday announced the 27th known lethal operation in President Trump’s campaign against drug cartels in South America.

item.title: Justice Dept. Won’t Meet Friday Deadline to Release All Epstein Files
item.description: Several members of Congress criticized the department’s No. 2, Todd Blanche, after he said more documents would be coming weeks late.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, said the Justice Department would not release all of its files relating to Jeffrey Epstein by Friday, the congressionally mandated deadline.

item.title: Erika Kirk Endorses JD Vance for 2028
item.description: The early backing of Ms. Kirk, the widow of Charlie Kirk, is notable because she now leads the influential conservative group he founded, Turning Point USA.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Olivier Touron/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Erika Kirk has taken on an increasingly prominent role in conservative politics.

item.title: Suspected Killer of M.I.T. Professor Studied With Victim, Graduating Top of Their Class
item.description: The parents of the suspect in the Brown and M.I.T. killings had not seen or heard from him since he left Portugal to enroll at a graduate program at Brown more than two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed, Dana Goldstein and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Bildagentur/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Claudio Neves Valente and Nuno Loureiro, the M.I.T. professor he is accused of killing, were classmates at the University of Lisbon’s Instituto Superior Técnico from 1995 to 2000.

item.title: Trump Administration Pauses Green Card Lottery After Brown Shooting
item.description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said President Trump had ordered the program to be suspended after it emerged that the shooting suspect had used it to obtain a green card.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said on Thursday that she had ordered the suspension of the diversity immigrant visa program.

item.title: Here is the latest.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed, Dana Goldstein, Maria Cramer and Soumya Karlamangla

item.title: Lumbee Tribe in North Carolina Gains Federal Recognition After Generations-Long Fight
item.description: The distinction for the Lumbee Tribe in North Carolina, signed into law on Thursday, opens access to federal support and defies challenges from other tribes over their legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Eduardo Medina and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press
item.media:description: John L. Lowery, center, the Lumbee Tribe chairman, led a toast to celebrate the passage of a bill granting the tribe federal recognition, in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Will Pay $450,000 to Wildfire Fighters With Cancer
item.description: They will be eligible for a one-time payment as well as college tuition for their children. The effort is part of a legislative push to address the dangers of working in toxic smoke.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Dreier
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a wildfire crew last August in San Luis Obispo County, Calif.

item.title: A Mysterious Death of a Teen Worker at a Nebraska Hog Farm
item.description: A 17-year-old worker died at a pork producer in Nebraska run by the governor’s family. Two investigations later, the boy’s mother is still searching for answers.
item.dc:creator: Yanqi Xu
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Beaver Valley Pork farm in St. Edward, Neb.

item.title: How the Army Caused Alarm in the Washington Skies Years Before a Fatal Crash
item.description: An aged helicopter fleet and inexperienced pilots from nearby Fort Belvoir had raised “widespread concern” among local pilots before a midair collision killed 67 people.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Helicopter helmets and a model of a Black Hawk helicopter on display in the home of Austin Roth, who served two decades in the Army, including as an instructor at Fort Belvoir in Virginia. The helmet on the top left is one Mr. Roth used while assigned to the 12th Aviation Battalion.

item.title: Florida Executed A Record 19 People in 2025. He Witnessed Them All.
item.description: John Koch, a radio reporter, witnesses every execution in Florida to keep close tabs on what he considers one of the most consequential actions the state takes.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: For John Koch, the rapid pace has meant watching an execution by lethal injection roughly once every two weeks over the past several months.

item.title: Suspect in MIT Professor’s Death Was an Ex-Classmate from Portugal, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Nuno F.G. Loureiro, the professor, and the man suspected in his killing attended the same physics program in Portugal during the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra, Francesca Regalado, Azam Ahmed and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Leah Willingham/Associated Press
item.media:description: People gathering outside the home of Nuno F.G. Loureiro in Brookline, Mass., on Tuesday.

item.title: Brown Shooting and an M.I.T. Professor’s Killing: What We Know
item.description: A single suspect carried out the shooting at Brown University and the killing of an M.I.T. professor, and was later found dead in New Hampshire, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the Barus and Holley building on the campus of Brown University, in Providence, R.I. on Tuesday.
